mainEntity.name: What is dual licensing in open-source software?

acceptedAnswer.text: Dual licensing in open-source software involves offering software under both an open-source license and a proprietary license. This approach allows software creators to engage with the community and establish a revenue model through commercial interests.

Developers release their software under an open-source license to encourage adoption and community contributions. Companies needing to use the software beyond open-source terms can purchase a proprietary license, allowing them to bypass open-source restrictions and providing developers with a revenue stream.

mainEntity.name: What are the benefits of dual licensing?

acceptedAnswer.text: The benefits of dual licensing include flexibility for diverse user bases, potential monetization through proprietary licenses, increased adoption and growth due to community involvement, and retained control over the software's commercial application.

mainEntity.name: Can you provide examples of dual licensing?

acceptedAnswer.text: Examples of dual licensing include MySQL, which offers its database management system under the GPL for open-source projects and a separate license for proprietary use, and Qt, which provides an open-source license alongside a commercial license, supporting diverse development needs.

mainEntity.name: Where can I learn more about open-source licenses?

acceptedAnswer.text: For more detailed insights into open-source licenses, including dual licensing strategies, visit the Open Source Initiative at https://opensource.org/.
